title: AXA Rosenberg sees new ways to predict volatility
text:
But there appears to be a relatively low level of comfort among investors and regulators about models built on AI.

“We spend quite a lot of time putting a human face on both the process and the performance,” Mr Smith said.

“So it’s one of the most important things as we drive to automation. It’s no good if a client or a regulator says, 'why did you buy that stock?' You can’t say, 'the computer said so.’

“That’s not going to fly, so there needs to be some transparency to the process and I’ve spent my career explaining how we do not build black boxes. Open up the lid and I can tell you how it works."

'Make yourself redundant'

Mr Smith’s working life to date has been based at the intersection of technology and markets.

“The day I joined the company I was told: 'Your job is to make yourself redundant. Automate away what you are doing and get the computer to do that and we will find you something more interesting to do.' We have never been short of ever-more interesting things to do,” he said.

While technology is improving all the time, that development doesn’t obviate the need for professional fund managers, he believes. “Models don’t have complete information,” Mr Smith said. Brexit and "those kinds of events" justify the continued existence of investors.

Not all markets have welcomed technological advances, but Australia is among those that have, Mr Smith said.

“In Australia, we have found that people are more open to those ideas. It’s tied up with a drive to lower fees and efficiencies associated with that. There is a comfort level with quantitative. It’s a more technical market on the whole, so people are more open to the idea of using quantitative.

“We see something similar in the Nordic markets. It’s less of the case in the UK,” the London-based investment manager said. “We still have traditional boards. They want to look their managers in the whites of their eyes and expect the managers to look at their investee companies in the whites of their eyes.”

Crowded trades?

A common criticism lobbed at computer-driven trading and investing is that it can lead to crowded trades, where investors head for the same corners of the market at the same time.

But Mr Smith believes crowded trades are more of an issue for the passive end of the spectrum than “smart-beta”, which falls somewhere in between the passive end and the active part of the market.

“I think that the impact of quantitative is less than the impact of passive. I still think there is this weight of assets, there has been a shift to smart beta, but it’s in infancy.

“I think that creates a certain type of inefficiency in the market that does create risks. I rely on other active managers out there moving prices around so that it creates efficiencies and opportunities,” he said, emphasising that investors shouldn’t conflate passive investing and automation.
description: Asset prices are high, interest rates are low and investors wonder how long markets will stay calm. AXA Rosenberg's CIO is working on the answer.
